abstract.p: Letter from Amy Allina (National Women's Health Network) says Oct 5 article on drug companies' influence shows how many groups that call themselves 'patient advocates' and 'health-research experts' are beholden to pharmaceutical industry

block.p: ''With Quiet, Unseen Ties, Drug Makers Sway Debate'' (front page, Oct. 5) showed how many groups that call themselves ''patient advocates'' and ''health-research experts'' are financially beholden to the pharmaceutical industry. A survey that our organization conducted in 1997 of the major sources of financing for women's-health and disease-specific organizations found that financial support from health-related companies was widespread.

''With Quiet, Unseen Ties, Drug Makers Sway Debate'' (front page, Oct. 5) showed how many groups that call themselves ''patient advocates'' and ''health-research experts'' are financially beholden to the pharmaceutical industry. A survey that our organization conducted in 1997 of the major sources of financing for women's-health and disease-specific organizations found that financial support from health-related companies was widespread.

Blatantly deceptive corporate front groups like the ones described in your article are the worst examples, but the work of other, seemingly independent organizations may be influenced by corporate contributors as well.
Your article reminds consumers, reporters and policy makers to ask these groups: Where does your financing come from, and what financial stake do your supporters have in the positions that you take?
AMY ALLINA Program and Policy Director National Women's Health Network Washington, Oct. 5, 2000
